actions.show-html-modal: Video tutorial (4 minutes)

actions.show-side-text: Sant Quirze de Pedret is a small medieval church in central Catalonia's Berguedà area, near the foothills of the Pyrenees and not far from an important historical route. The Llobregat River, one of the territory's main waterways, flows nearby.

Originally constructed at the end of the ninth century, the church’s architecture has changed a great deal over the years and its walls have been decorated at two different times with the painting of figurative murals.


Image source: Diputació de Barcelona

The original ninth-century church had a single nave crowned by a quadrangular vaulted apse. Later, in the middle of the 10th century, the church was enlarged with two aisles ending in vaulted horseshoe-shaped apses. As far as we know, the first pictorial decoration was limited to the back wall of the apse and one wall of the original nave, which depicted a crucifixion.


Image source: Diputació de Barcelona

The compositions that originally occupied the back of the apse consist of two medallions with figures. One of the figures is a bearded male with open arms in a prayerful attitude. The other is a warrior on horseback and the image is enclosed by a medallion at the center of a cross. Other figures of different proportions complete the imagery, which it has not yet been possible to interpret. The paintings can be dated to the middle of the 10th or early 11th century.

Later, a second and more expansive layer of Romanesque-style frescoes covered the earlier paintings. The renewed decoration was the result of an ambitious iconographic programme whose authorship, as usual, is unknown. The frescoes include a complex apocalyptic cycle, quite unusual for Romanesque art in the Pyrenees. Other subjects worth noting are a rare personification of the Church and two hagiographic scenes of the martyr patron saint Cyricus and his mother Julitta. Also, a second crucifixion was painted directly over the earlier one.

At some point in the 13th century, an incident of unknown nature changed the appearance of the building. One of the main consequences was that most of the Romanesque paintings were hidden behind new walls. Only the frescoes of the south apse remained uncovered.

parades.title: Discovery and removal of the paintings

actions.show-side-text: At the end of the 19th century, the visible paintings were “discovered” and made known to the public. Throughout the 20th century, all of the frescoes were systematically uncovered and removed in two different campaigns using the same procedure, the strappo technique, which consists in the removal of the surface layer of wall paintings. All the removed fragments are now preserved in two museums: the National Art Museum of Catalonia (in Barcelona) and the Diocesan Museum of Solsona (in Solsona). In addition, some fragments of paintings and the deep layer are still preserved in the church. Unfortunately, the two crucifixions are lost.

Ultimately, for anyone who wants to figure out how the painted walls of the medieval church in Pedret once looked, it is necessary to visit three places: Pedret, Barcelona and Solsona. Currently, the fragmentary paintings of Pedret must be studied as if they were an intriguing puzzle.

At the end of the ninth century, a very simple church was built as part of the organisation of a territory marked by scattered settlement. The church had a nave and a quadrangular apse covered with a vault. A door in the western façade gave access to the building.

In the 10th century, the first church was completely renovated and enlarged. The height of the nave was raised and open windows were installed on the south side. The apse was also raised and covered by a new horseshoe-shaped vault. Lastly, two aisles and two small horseshoe-shaped apses were added. Owing to the steep topographical features of the site, the aisle and the apse on the north side were built at a higher level. The aisles opened onto the central nave by means of two horseshoe arches on each side. A door in the south aisle marked the new entrance.

Between the second half of the 10th century and the beginning of the 11th century, the church received its first pictorial decorations. The main apse featured depictions of two figures surrounded by a clipeus, one of those cross-shaped; and a crucifixion was displayed in the nave.

The walls of the church were decorated with a new series of frescoes in the Romanesque style, which covered the earlier ones. An apocalyptic cycle, quite unusual for Romanesque churches in the Pyrenees, decorated the main apse. Other notable features included two hagiographic scenes of the martyred patron saint Cyricus and his mother Julitta on the main arch; the Parable of the Wise and Foolish Virgins and a unique personification of the Church in the south apsidiole; and a new crucifixion covering the earlier one.

An incident of unknown nature, perhaps a fire, must have been catastrophic, since two-thirds of the south nave collapsed. As a result, it became necessary to carry out major alterations to the church and important parts of the mural paintings were covered over. Specifically, the southern nave was removed, the central nave was covered with a vault, which made it necessary to reinforce the walls, and a new door was opened on the south side of the nave.
Earliest church has one nave with a quadrangular vaulted apse.
Building enlargement adds two lateral aisles with vaulted horseshoe-shaped apses.

actions.show-side-text: First pictorial setting features two saints in the main apse and a crucifixion in the nave.
Some interventions occur but do not alter the structure of the building.

parades.title: Late 11th century or first quarter of the 12th century

actions.show-side-text: The walls of the church are decorated with a new set of Romanesque-style frescoes that cover the previous ones.

A catastrophic incident changes the appearance of the building. Most of the Romanesque paintings are hidden behind new walls. The southern nave is removed, the central nave is covered with a vault that makes it necessary to reinforce the walls, and a new door is opened on the south side of the nave.
Jean-August Brutails publishes the first Catalan Romanesque frescoes of the Pyrenees: Sant Martí of Fenollar and La Clusa.
First papers are published on the rediscovered frescoes of Pedret: Francesc Muns, “Sant Quirze de Pedret”; and Josep Puiggarí, "Pintures murals a Pedret"
The Institut d'Estudis Catalans publishes the first issue of "Les pintures murals catalanes" dedicated to Pedret, with colour reproductions of the frescoes.
Throughout the 20th century, many Catalan frescoes are uncovered and, from 1919 onwards, removed using the strappo technique to preserve them.
First strappo campaign takes place at Pedret. Frescoes in the north and south apses are removed and sent to the National Art Museum of Catalonia (Barcelona).

During the Spanish Civil War (1936-1939), the two layers of frescoes in the main apse are removed for storage in Barcelona. Unfortunately, the two crucifixions disappear.

The deposed frescoes of the main apse are sent to the Diocesan Museum of Solsona.
The isolated church of Sant Quirze is ceded by the diocese of Solsona to the municipality of Cercs. First restoration campaign is led by architect Camil Pallàs.
Second restoration campaign is led by architect Camil Pallàs.

The local heritage service of the Barcelona provincial government starts an intensive restoration programme of the whole complex, including an archaeological campaign, led by architect Antoni González.
Rediscovery of the frescoes on the main arch, the only ones preserved in situ, occurs. However, the reproduction of the frescoes in the main and south apses destroys part of the deep layers.
The church of Pedret opens to the public visit after the restoration.
New museography of the Pedret room opens at the Solsona museum, featuring the history of the church and its pictorial decorations using a digital model.

actions.show-side-text: To figure out how the medieval painted walls of the church looked, we must visit three places: Pedret, Barcelona and Solsona. These days, Sant Quirze de Pedret is a monument in fragments, and its study is like solving a puzzle with many separate and missing pieces. This is the problem we want to solve with EHEM.

stories.title: B. Medieval iconography of the paintings
▹ B1. The salvation is within the church

actions.show-side-text:
The iconography within the north and south apsidioles distinctly underscores the Church's role in securing salvation. The apses are not merely artistic expressions but also integral to understanding the Church as a spiritual institution.
The suggested viewing sequence begins with the south apse, which sets the stage for a journey of salvation and spiritual enlightenment.

At the entrance to the south apse, an enigmatic seated figure, identified only by the fragment 'SCS [ ]VS', sparks debate over its identity. Proposed figures include Saint Matthew, referencing a depicted parable inside the apse, and the Pope Saint Gregory, who may embody the late 11th-century ecclesiastical reform, known as “gregorian reform”. The south apse delineates the Church's representation in three distinct stages.

At the apex, there is a portrayal of the infant Jesus Christ, clutching a scroll, seated on the Virgin Mary's lap and surrounded by an aureole or mandorla. The imagery symbolizes Christ's incarnation and his role as founder of the Christian Church.

show-image-interval: https://ehem.virvig.eu/imgs/GM000007-South apse paintings - Mary with de child.jpg

actions.show-side-text: The Church's terrestrial phase is depicted by means of a double visual metaphor. Next to the entrance, at the visitor’s right-hand side, there is the church personified as a crowned lady seated on a church-like edifice, reflecting the ethos of the Gregorian Reform. However, this iconography, with few parallels, notably in southern Italy, raises questions about its cultural transmission to Catalonia.

The rest of the wall’s central area illustrates the parable of the wise and foolish virgins, with the wise virgins seated at a table with Christ. The juxtaposition of natural and metaphorical light, through burning and extinguished torches, underscores the theme of spiritual preparedness for salvation

The dado area, adorned with greyish fictive curtains, is in a state of partial preservation, leaving the original subject matter that decorated the curtains indiscernible. One hypothesis is that the scenes may depict hunting or pastoral themes.
The north apsidiole must be regarded as complementary to the south apsidiole in iconographic terms.

Saint Peter, holding the keys, is prominently positioned among the apostles, not merely by virtue of his central placement but also because of his depiction on a chair-like throne reminiscent of a cathedra. This specific portrayal is symbolically significant, as it alludes to the doctrine of the primacy of Saint Peter, thereby indirectly referencing the supremacy of the Roman papacy.

stories.title: ▹ B2. The Apocalypse awaits at the central apse

actions.show-side-text: The main chapel of Pedret exhibits a remarkable apocalyptic programme, intricately weaving elements from the Book of Revelation into its design. When viewed collectively, the images adorning the walls provide a cohesive and distinct narrative context.

At the vault, the Maiestas Domini surrounded by the four living creatures presides the main chapel. The iconography of the four living creatures is a combination of two biblical sources: ,Rev. 4:7 and Ez. 1:5-9

Of these symbolic figures, only two are distinctly recognizable in their preserved state. The lion, depicted holding a book, represents St. Mark the Evangelist. The figure of an ox, also holding a book, symbolizes St. Luke the Evangelist. The depiction of an eagle symbolizing St. John the Evangelist can only be surmised. Unfortunately, the representation of the angel, an emblem of St. Matthew the Evangelist, has faded into decay and is no longer recognizable

Dominating the space is the “Dextera Domini” or “Hand of God”, rendered in the upper soffit of the window, flanked by two birds.  Above, a vacant throne with the roll of the seven seals, placed on a cushion, hints at the concept of “etimasia”. The vertical alignment continues upwards to the place where the “Agnus Dei” should be, identified by an inscription at the wall's apex.

actions.show-html-modal:
The east wall of the main chapel

At the heart of the visual arrangement of the chapel lies the flat wall to the east, where the components are meticulously arrayed.

actions.show-side-text: On either side of the axis, the twenty-four elders are shown in adoration of the Lamb, a key element of the narrative. Although the Lamb has yet to break the seals, this does not preclude the presence of the four horsemen of the Apocalypse, depicted on the south wall of the apse.
The apocalyptic story continues along the east part of the south wall, where the four horsemen of the Apocalypse are depicted in two superimposed rows.
The scene shows the opening of the first four seals, which corresponds to Rev. 6:1-8:

The first and second horsemen are depicted in the upper register. Although the attributes have been lost, they can be distinguished by the colour of their horses, which are white and red, respectively. As the first horseman has appeared earlier, he has been represented preceding the second, who is located just next to the corner, touching the enclosing wall. The same order is followed by the riders in the lower register, where we can distinguish, from east to west, an afflicted figure, apparently without a horse, and, further on, the third rider. The latter, who rides a black horse, is the only one with preserved traces of the scales that he carries as an attribute.

The north wall retains other scenes linked to the opening of the seven seals. Specifically, the opening of the fifth seal continues in the easternmost section of the north wall. A group of six busts, some of which look like children, are dressed in white robes and represent the souls of the martyrs.

show-image-interval: https://ehem.virvig.eu/imgs/GM000030-Paintings central apse-north wall-altar with the souls of the martyrs.jpg

actions.show-side-text: The opening of the fith seal: the cry of the martyrs (Rev. 6: 9-11)

The altar, which has been placed above the souls of the martyrs as the biblical text says, is a very prominent feature. It is richly adorned with a lavishly decorated tablecloth. A paten and a chalice rest on the altar table. A crown of light hangs above the altar, which has been enriched with a canopy of wreathed columns. Next to it is an inscription that would identify it as ALTARE.

An unfolded white fabric below the busts of the martyrs represents heaven, as has recently been made clear. The inscription COELO makes the matter explicit. Above the scroll of the sky, four stars are arrayed.

The only illustration of the sixth seal is the passage of the disappearance of heaven, which is like a scroll being rolled up, as attested in Rev. 6:14:
Sixth Seal: Cosmic Disturbances 
Then the sky receded as a scroll when it is rolled up, and every mountain and island was moved out of its place.
The apocalyptic account continues with the seventh seal, where an angel appears and sets fire to the altar. In Pedret, the angel burns the altar above the martyrs.
This figure merge to apocalyptic passages, Rev. 8,3 and 6,9.

In the lower register, below the sky, three haloed figures have been preserved. Their state of preservation is very fragmentary, but they could perhaps represent the angels with the trumpets or some other apocalyptic episode that we cannot now identify with certainty.

In Rev. 8,2 the angels with trumpets follow the seventh seal:
And I saw the seven angels who stand before God, and to them were given seven trumpets.

In the middle of the south wall, a giant seraph divides the scenes of the opening of the first seals amid a large group of figures. Probably another seraph or perhaps a cherub was at the centre of the north wall, facing the first one described above.

actions.show-html-modal: The seraph with the inscriptions SANCTVS, SANCTVS, SANCTVS

actions.show-side-text: Additionally, the side walls are adorned with separate groups of angelic figures all under the watchful eye of a “Maiestas Domini”, surrounded by the four living creatures.
A fictive curtain features hybrid beings and sea-monsters that are encircled in medallions.

The eastern third of the central apse contains a series of images with busts of saints, various biblical episodes and some stories of the martyrdom of Saint Quirze and his mother, patron saint of the church of Pedret. They are the forerunners of the faith.

The wall of the triumphal arch facing the nave is organized in sections framed by bands with different ornamental motifs. The horizontal ones have shapes that imitate precious stones, while the vertical ones are two-coloured bands separated by pearlescence. Rather large fleurs-de-lis mark the entire vertical length of the corner. At the top of the wall, a band of meanders in perspective extends to the first section of the nave’s adjacent walls. The meanders are interrupted by rectangles inscribed with busts of saints identified by inscriptions.
The Old Testament scene of the sacrifice of Isaac is depicted on the north side of the wall.

Abraham, dressed in a robe and cloak, is holding a knife with which he is about to sacrifice his son. Isaac, bare-chested and covered only with a skirt-like piece of clothing, seems unaware of the weapon that threatens him. Near the patriarch, only an A from the inscription that identified Abraham is preserved.

The scene depicts two standing figures whose identities have not been resolved. One of them is better preserved and corresponds to the figure of a soldier in profile, wearing a nasal helmet and chain mail. Of the other, only part of a nimbus and a sumptuous cloak are visible. It has been suggested that the scene portrays the encounter between Abraham, dressed as a soldier, and Melchizedek.

In the middle register, two episodes are painted from the passion of Saint Quirze, the titular saint of the church at Pedret. On the north side is a figure, the Roman prefect, seated on a bejewelled chair, while behind him stands a soldier. The vertical inscription preserved perhaps indicates the figure of the prefect. Nearly all the rest has been lost: only the white strings of a whip have survived.

On the other side, Saint Julitta, her torso bared, and her son, Quirze, gaze upwards, from where rays emerge. Both figures wear a nimbus. An inscription identifies Saint Juliet SANCTA IVLITA. Another inscription which is partially preserved probably indicates the executioner who is torturing the saints, although we cannot recognize the actual torment. From the standing position of the figures, one may think of the episode of the pot of pitch.

On the intrados of the triumphal arch is a cycle of Cain and Abel in paintings framed by bands of jewel-like separating strips. The paintings are rather badly preserved and their damage is particularly evident in the northern part where there is a considerable loss of pictorial material.
.

The figure of Abel, on the north side, is very deteriorated. Only the bust is preserved, and it is difficult to make out the animal that he is raising towards the divine hand. 
The brothers make their offerings on both sides of the Hand of God, as is recounted in Genesis 4:2-5:
Now Abel was a keeper of sheep, but Cain was a tiller of the ground. And in the process of time it came to pass that Cain brought an offering of the fruit of the ground to the Lord. Abel also brought of the firstborn of his flock and of their fat. And the Lord respected Abel and his offering, but He did not respect Cain and his offering. And Cain was very angry, and his countenance fell.

The other scene depicted on the same side of the intrados, which we do not know whether it is that of Cain slaying Abel, has been lost. Only an isolated patch of painting remains. On the south side, to the left of the Hand of God, Cain, dressed luxuriously, offers a sheaf of wheat. Next to it is a vertical inscription with his name, ḲAIṂ.
Below the offering is another scene, partially preserved, which again shows Cain standing with an axe resting on his shoulder. Three inscriptions, KAIM, DESTERA DOMINI and ABEL, indicate the necessary presence of the three figures mentioned, i.e. God, Cain and Abel. The divine hand is intuited in the upper right-hand corner. Unfortunately, the area corresponding to Abel has been lost and we are therefore unable to restore the scene in its entirety.

The scene corresponds to the following dialogue between God and Cain in Genesis 4:9-10:

Then the Lord said to Cain, “Where is Abel your brother?” 
He said, “I do not know. Am I my brother’s keeper?” 
And He said, “What have you done? The voice of your brother’s blood cries out to Me from the ground.

stories.title: ▹ B4. The dangers of the world

actions.show-side-text:
All the lower parts of the three apses and the eastern area of the central nave are decorated with fictive curtains. The lower parts of the wall of the triumphal arch that looks to the main nave are covered with a frieze of meanders in perspective. As is usual in the decoration of the church, rectangles with figures are interspersed between the meanders. Unfortunately, only one has survived on the north wall. It depicts a naked human figure wielding a spear and riding a gigantic bird.

Below them hang fictive curtains with medallions, like those described in the apse plinths. The medallion on the north wall contains a double-tailed mermaid. An inscription SERENA confirms the identity of the figure. Only traces of the meanders in perspective remain on the south wall. A quadruped is the protagonist of the preserved medallion, in this case without an inscription. The animal represents a hedgehog with fruit nailed to its quills, as imagined in medieval bestiaries.

actions.show-side-text: During the second campaign to remove paintings from the church of Sant Quirze de Pedret, three fragments of the previous decorative campaign were discovered. Two fragments were found in the central apse, under the Romanesque paintings, symmetrically placed on either side of the window on the eastern wall. They were removed to the Solsona museum, where they are known as "the Orant" (or Praying Man) and "the Knight".

Although the two paintings are of modest quality and difficult to identify, they represent two pieces of the church's early ornamentation, dating from shortly after the 10th-century enlargement. They are thought to represent two saints and were probably completed with other subjects.

parades.title: Central nave: Christ on the cross

actions.show-side-text: The other fragment was found on the north wall of the central nave, next to the westernmost arch. It also consisted of two superimposed layers of paintings, both layers depicting the same subject, the figure of Christ on the cross. Whereas nothing is known about the latter fragment, the earlier one remained in the church, unremoved, and was still visible in 1960, before being lost.

Pedret's Romanesque paintings exhibit great technical mastery and a very good knowledge of the nature of the materials. The techniques used were the typical ones employed in Romanesque murals: fresco and lime painting.

The wall to be painted was levelled to apply, first, a mortar of lime and coarse sand (arriccio) and then, a layer of thinner mortar (intonaco). The second layer, while still damp, was painted with pigments diluted with water. The carbonation of the lime amalgamated the pigments with the wall, without the need for a binder. This is the process known as fresco painting.

As the mortar takes a short time to dry, fresco was used only for the first layers of paint and the backgrounds. For any final details, such as parts of the faces, folds of clothing, and decorative elements, the "lime painting" process was used. This consists of wetting the wall when it is dry and applying the pigments bound with lime water.

The pigments of the Pedret paintings are characteristic of fresco painting. For the reds and yellows, they are earths and oxides; for the whites, the same lime, and for the blacks, carbon black. It is worth noting the use of the blue pigment aerinite to make some mixtures of green. Aerinite is a mineral of local origin that is frequently found in Romanesque paintings in the Pyrenees.

stories.title: ▹ D2. How to paint a face

actions.show-side-text: The painting of a face usually relies on what has been called the “triad of colours”: a light-toned background that is generally light ochre, a darker tone to mark the shadows, and a lighter one for the highlights. The tones are schematically superimposed one on top of the other. This system appears in a 13th-century treatise on artistic technology called "Schedula diversarum artium" by Theophilus Presbyter, whose encyclopaedic work summarises different artistic traditions.

The triad of colours formed the base. Depending on a painter's skills and available means, however, the shades could be extended with intermediate tones, as can be seen in this sketch of one of the virgins, where up to five shades were used in addition to white for the lights and the final black to outline the contours.

actions.show-html-modal:
1. 1. Very light pink ochre base colour, applied flat to the entire surface.
  2. 2. Tone of the same range but more intense to highlight the left contour, nose, eyebrows, chin and eye bag.
  3. 3. The same more intense tone to accentuate the profiles of these parts.
  4. 4. Pale pink for the reliefs.
  5. 5. Darker pink applied on top to highlight the cheekbones and lips.

stories.title: ▹ E1. Why the wall paintings are not in the church?

actions.show-side-text: In modern times, most of the church walls were covered with white plaster, but the paintings in the southern apsidiole, which then served as a sacristy, were always visible.
They were the first Catalan Romanesque paintings to be studied and published at the end of the 19th century by Francesc Muns and Josep Puiggarí.
In 1907, a series of publications entitled "Las pintures murals catalanes" began to appear, and the first one was dedicated to the paintings of Sant Quirze de Pedret.
The Pedret paintings that appeared in print were the ones known up to that time and, therefore, the ones that it was decided to remove in the campaign carried out between 1919 and 1923.

Specifically, the paintings in the south and north apses were removed in June 1921. Along with the Italian technician Franco Steffanoni, the curator Emili Gandia was also at Pedret acting on behalf of the Barcelona museum. Gandia discovered the paintings that decorated the main apse, but, in addition to the paintings in the south apse, only the frescoes from the north apse were removed while those from the central apse were left.

During the Spanish Civil War (1936-1939), the main altarpiece was destroyed, and the church was converted into a warehouse. In 1937, Ramon Gudiol removed the paintings from the main apse, the triumphal arch and the nave.

At the time, two fragments were discovered underneath the Romanesque paintings. Reflecting earlier decoration from around the year 1000, the paintings were removed for storage in Gudiol's private workshop until the war’s conclusion in 1939, when they were collected by the director of the Diocesan Museum of Solsona.

stories.title: ▹ E2. The process to detach a fresco from its wall

actions.show-side-text: The technique used to remove Pedret's paintings is known as strappo. Strappo is a method of transposing fresco paintings by which the pictorial layer is separated from the underlying mortar layers of the wall by affixing it to a thin, flexible, easily transportable fabric support and then attaching the backing to another rigid support. The strappo method, which came into use in the 18th century, underwent improvement at the end of the 19th century, especially in northern Italy. Franco Steffanoni and Arturo Cividini, who were responsible for the removal of the Romanesque paintings in Catalonia between 1919 and 1923, came from Bergamo in northern Italy.

The procedure is as follows. Thick cotton cloths, or extraction cloths, are attached to the painted surface with highly concentrated, water-soluble glue of animal origin. During drying, the glued cloths shrink tightly and pull away the paint layer, which remains adhered to the fabric. On large surfaces, the paintings are divided into fragments and the process is repeated for each fragment. Once pulled off, the fabrics are easily rolled up and can be moved.
When the fragments reach their new destination, the fabrics are cleaned and the back is affixed to another fabric, called transfer teal, by means of a water-soluble glue, in this case, casein glue.
Once the glue dries, the fabrics used for the extraction are removed with hot water, leaving visible the torn and hooked paints on the new transfer cloth.
The fragments are placed on a new, rigid support, which in the Barcelona Museum were reproductions of the apses on a scale of 1:1, built of wood and plaster.

The mural paintings of Sant Quirze de Pedret are no longer in the church. They were removed in two separate campaigns, in 1921 and 1937, and are now kept in two different museums:  the National Art Museum of Catalonia (in Barcelona) and the Diocesan Museum of Solsona (in Solsona).

actions.show-html-modal: Where are the frescoes

parades.title: Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya, Barcelona

actions.show-side-text: The paintings of the lateral apses are in Barcelona.

parades.title: Museu Diocesà i Comarcal de Solsona

actions.show-side-text: The decoration of the central apse, the triumphal arch and the nave are in Solsona. Two fragments from the first decorative layer are also preserved in Solsona.

The paintings of the lateral apses were removed in 1921, transferred to Barcelona and integrated into a new installation of Romanesque painting that opened in 1924. Their display made use of a pioneering approach: a 1:1 scale reproduction of the original architecture. The paintings from the south apse were installed in a purpose-built apsidiole that was not, however, a perfect match with the original, so fabrics were added that are still perceptible. Also, the paintings in the north apsidiole were displayed as flat fragments, lined with lime plaster. Then, in 1934, the museum moved to the Palau Nacional de Montjuïc, where it remains today.
When the museum underwent renovations in 1972, the fragments from the north apsidiole were installed in a new architectural reproduction, so that they have been displayed side by side ever since.

parades.title: Second detachment campaign during the Civil War

actions.show-side-text: In 1937, during the Civil War, the paintings were removed from the central apse, the triumphal arch, and the nave, including the two fragments of earlier decoration that had appeared underneath in the apse. These paintings were also taken to Barcelona, but in this case, they went to the workshop of Josep M. Gudiol's team at Casa Amatller, where the fragments were transferred to wooden supports.

In 1940, they were reclaimed by the director of the Diocesan Museum of Solsona, Antoni Llorens, who came to collect them personally. Initially, they were displayed in a room whose height did not allow for a complete reproduction of the apse, so the paintings of the lower parts were simply displayed on the walls. When the museum underwent renovations in 1982, however, they were moved to their current room, which faithfully reproduces the nave and apse of the original church.

The paintings in the Solsona Museum went through restoration in 2018 and 2021 with cleaning, consolidation, and pigment analysis. These efforts detected the presence of additions and occasional illusionist restorations.

parades.title: Reproduction and recreation of the paintings in the church

actions.show-side-text: Back in the original church in Pedret, comprehensive restoration work carried out by the Barcelona provincial government between 1989 and 1995 enhanced the remains of the original paintings, and reproductions and recreations of the paintings were put on display in the apses.
